captions.text:

unless somebody pushes
the button.

It's yours,
if you want it.

Look at it go, Homer.
This one's gonna go for miles.

title: October Sky (11/11) Movie CLIP - This One's Gonna Go for Miles (1999) HD

comments.author: anti0918

comments.text:
I forgot just how good this movie is. Watched it the other day again for 
the first time in a while, and man is it inspirational! I remember my high 
school physics teacher showed us this, and we built rockets and launched 
them. Good times, and a good way to spark interest in science and 
technology.﻿
comments.author: Tyler Parcell

comments.text:
I love this movie so much. It's based on West Virginia, but actually all of 
it was filmed here in Tennessee not far from where I live. I got to see 
some of it being filmed. My old town mayor is actually an extra in this 
movie. My father had a somewhat similar life, because his father was a coal 
miner. While my father didn't turn out to be some rocket scientist, he did 
have a better life than what his father did...he is retired Air Force and 
an engineer. But my father wouldn't be the man he is without the support of 
his father working in those coal mines. He did what he had to do, was a 
very tough man. His father in this movie reminds me a lot of my 
grandpa...working in the mines was rough on him.﻿
comments.author: LucidDream

comments.text: One of my favourite movies, *tears* ~><~﻿

comments.author: Rhys Belding

comments.text:
A student of mine, his mother told me he wants to be an astronaut or a 
scientist for Nasa, and yet he's never heard of the start of it all. I'm 
going to give him this movie for Christmas, I just hope he feels some 
inspiration like I did when my dad showed me this years and years ago ﻿
comments.author: Bostonterrierslol

comments.text:
+Kopihucky +Shea Lee As a teacher I encourage my students to all follow 
their dreams no matter how absurd. One of them wants to be a doctor and 
wants this at 10 years old, another wants to be a vet, two of them want to 
be martial arts masters, and so on. Seeing their progress and thinking 
about how far they have to go, it may be a little selfish for saying this, 
but makes me feel like Miss Riley in a way that's why when I think of my 
students, I think of her and this wonderful movie.
comments.author: Bostonterrierslol

comments.text:
Show him the V1 rockets.. that is what really started it all... or you 
could even go back further when the chinese developed gun powder and built 
rockets
comments.author: Kopihucky

comments.text: How did he like it?
comments.author: Shea Lee

comments.text:
As cheesy as this sounds, this is probably one of the most meaningful gifts 
that is in a form of a film that you can ever give to anybody who hasn't 
seen it. This scene really hits home, and I fucking love it. I really hope 
your student was positively moved by this film as I was, further inspiring 
him to work harder towards achieving his goal of becoming an astronaut. 
(Also, from a personal stance, I really appreciate teachers like you who 
continue to inspire young men and woman to becoming the person they want to 
be!)

comments.author: JohnnyDinh75

comments.text:
I never saw a trailer for this movie when I first heard about it. I only 
heard it was about a kid that wants to build rockets and eventually work at 
NASA. I didn't even know the time period it was set in. So my immediate 
thought was some kind of modern sci fi movie with a lot of technical 
jargon. I was pleasantly surprised at what this movie turned out to be. No 
sc fi. No big special effects. Just a really great story about 
perseverance. One of my favorites of all time.﻿
comments.author: BM

comments.text: Every time I watch this movie I cry.﻿

comments.text:
+Eric Thomson The title is CLIPS. Nobody made you click it, and nobody 
promised anything. And, especially, no one said you could jump to any plot 
point for any movie. If you expect there to be a cornucopia of free movie 
endings on YouTube you are going to be completely shocked by how the real 
world works.

comments.author: NessaLoveWoahxP

comments.text:
The feeling Homer Hickam showed when his father showed up, was how I felt 
tonight, when my father made it to our last performance of our play "the 
servant of two masters". :) no greater feeling to me. I don't blame him for 
not making the first few, because of work. But that's what makes my father 
my hero. And it's not when he's there with us, it's because he's there for 
us. I mean tonight was the night almost teared up after the show and saw my 
father. I'm also proud to see my friends from when I was younger. We'll all 
remember, Conroe high school theatre department made history after 87 years 
of making it to regionals. And though we're not going to state, were proud 
of how far we've gotten. My father is proud of all of us, and everyone else 
in our city showed support.:)﻿
comments.author: Justin Suarez

comments.author: GOWRI SANKAR

comments.text:
I think what makes this scene/movie work is because we all have seen 'kids 
with big dreams' movies before, but those movies are mostly about dreams 
about going to the big city, or to become a star or something self centered 
like that. Here it's about something more personal and that's something you 
don't see a lot of in movies especially for younger audiences. This is a 
GREAT movie for kids.﻿
comments.author: Dank Happenings Productions

comments.text: You're right.  It's a great movie for kids because it celebrates LEARNING.

comments.author: Steve Evets

comments.text:
I just finished re-reading the book that the movie was based on. Some 
things in the movie didn't actually happen (Homer didn't go into the mine 
to work; Miss Riley actually lived several years after the movie ended; 
etc.). But most of the book and movie matched up. I love this movie! And 
Chris Cooper (Homer's dad) is an amazing actor. He just seems like he is 
really the character, doesn't he?

comments.text:
It's Coalwood, WV. Big Creek H.S. is in War, WV, a couple of miles away. 
I've seen it but it was just closed, about a year ago.
comments.author: dgoren121692

comments.text:
No, but I've been to the real site in Coalwood, WV, and it looks very 
similar. It's actually much closer to the center of town than in the movie. 
O'Dell's dad, in his 80's, drove me around what's left of the town. I'll 
never forget it. That was ten years ago or so. Many homes were boarded-up 
because they shut that mine down.
comments.author: dgoren121692

comments.text:
I'm a grown man of 52. Pretty tough (I've always though). I get teary-eyed 
when I see this, because my Dad was a lot like Homer's dad. He was a former 
Marine Drill Instructor that died when I was 11 without ever putting his 
arm around me or telling me he was proud of me or loved me. It still 
affects me but I have two sons that I tell it to. If I was Homer in this 
movie, that one gesture would have meant the world to me
comments.author: dgoren121692

comments.text:
He wasn't cruel, he was old fashioned. Homer was trying to break the mold, 
John had been in coal mining for his life and he came from a generation 
grounded...Homer wanted to fly and get out and John couldn't accept it at 
first, but finally, he came to realize that Home really could do it and he 
finally did accept his son's newfound choice and profession.. I'm still 
waiting for my dad to accept my religion, this scene is beautiful to me...
